summary: Male breast cancer (MBC) is a cancer that originates in the breasts of males. It is much less common than breast cancer in females, accounting for less than 1% of new breast cancer cases worldwide. While many treatment strategies are adopted from female breast cancer, MBC can have distinct presentations, associations, and genetic factors.
causes: Genetic mutations (BRCA1, BRCA2, CHEK2, PALB2, PTEN, ATM, RAD51L3)
Tumor protein P53 gene mutations (associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome)
DNA mismatch repair gene mutations (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, EpCAM) (associated with Lynch syndrome)
PTEN gene mutations (associated with Cowden syndrome)
risk_factors: Consumption of hormonal drugs for gender reassignment therapy
Occupations with long-term exposure to high temperatures, petrol emissions, or exhaust emissions
Gynecomastia (historically considered, but not definitively established as a risk factor)
diagnosis: Physical examination (checking for lumps, lymph node enlargement)
Needle biopsy (fine-needle aspiration or core needle biopsy)
subtypes: Papillary carcinomas of the breast (in situ, encapsulated, solid-papillary, invasive)
Invasive cribriform carcinoma of the breast
